p.s: Michel Barnier mentioned from the beginning, that he is not happy with the Brexit (l. 1-3), but he acceptesaccepts the decision of the UK and offers solutions for future problems, by pointing out that third country deals in the EU Single Market can work like f.e. with the US.
He makes also clear that the EU can better survive with outwithout UK than the UK without the EU (l. 27-28).
Thisthese arguments make for him sure to stay strong and dominant and to let the UK think that they have to make compromissescompromises not them.

He wants to make sure that the UK knows that the best solution would be a deal which includes similar financial relationships is possible and got already realized with the USA, but at the same time he points out that the UK will have to holar to the EU's regulations (l. 20-21).
Michel Barnier is choosing a kind, but also dominant style of language, which is pointing out that the EU is in a better position but is open for a deal too.
The speaker is using often the pronouns we or our which he is using to make the unity in the EU stronger and to say to the EU's public he can survive without UK too.

Michel Barnier is also pointing his opinion out by stylistic devices, like This is what the G20 calls derence, what you call in the US substitute compliance, and we call in the EU equivalence (l. 22-23), which is a parallelism which has the function, that is to show the EU's dominance, by mentioning that the USA is calling compliance the G20 calls deference, but the EU still calls it equivalence.

In the metaphor framework (l. 29), he is pointing out how glad he is about the EU's open market and the jurisdiction and that it should be a privilege that the UK's industry could potentially be again part of it.
In line 26 Michel Barnier is using a rethoricalrhetorical question, to make his argument that the UK industry can work as good as the US industry in the EU's equivalence system stronger.
